lines.text: 59, I mean 10 o'clock!
Well, Mrs. Murdoch, you know what the book says about the early bird.
There are no worms here.
Well, you can't tell what you're liable to find in an old barn like this.
Oh, you're not quite what I expected, Mr. Shayne.
Well, what did you expect - top hat, striped trousers and cutaway?
Hardly - something fat and exported with dirty fingernails chewing on a filthy cigar butt and with its hat on its head.
[Mrs. Murdoch suspects her gold-digging daughter-in-law of stealing and selling one of her most valuable coins]
So what's worrying you the most?
Both. I'm hiring you to get the doubloon back and arrange for a divorce for my son without cost to me.
Suppose she didn't take it?
I expect you to prove that she did and I'm asking no questions.

[to Murdoch]
Well, business is really picking up when the worm comes to the early bird.
Is Mrs. Morny in?
She's not home.
Wait a minute. How do you know if you don't ask her?
She already told me.
Oh, by the way, what did she look like?
She?
Well, all right then. What did *he* look like?
Oh, you mean the party that sold me the doubloon?
Yeah.

Well, let me see... He was middle-aged, heavy set, about 5'7", weighing about 175 pounds. He wore a blue suit, black shoes, green tie and brown-bordered handkerchief. His hair was gray. There was a mole on his nose and a long scar...
What about that hole in his right sock?
I neglected to remove his shoes.
Why are we whispering?
We lost our voices.
And don't leave town. We want a statement!
You can have the one the bank sent me. You'll get a great laugh out of that.
[Murdoch enters Morny's club at the end of a fistfight]
Well, I see the slaughter has started already. Sorry I'm late.
You're too early to suit me. Get out and stay out.
I was under the impression that your trap was open to the public.
It's not open to rats.
There you are. All this extra service I throw in free.
You know, you're not a bad brand of trouble, Mike. I'm sorry our friendship has to be so short.
What do you mean short? As long as I think you have the doubloon, I have to keep an eye on you.
Then you don't believe me?
Nope. You see, my mama told me never to trust a beautiful woman any further than I could throw her and I don't know how far that is now.
All right. Come on, Shayne, I'm anxious to hear all about it.
You better take a look in there.
Oh yeah? Sight unseen, I'll lay odds somebody's dead.
[last lines]
Say, how long are you going to be in Reno?
Just six weeks.
That's swell. I'll give you a ring the moment you get back to town.
You will? I may hold you to that.
To what?
I have a first class witness in Lieutenant Breeze that you're going to marry me. Driver, Union Depot, please.
Hey, wait a minute. You can't do that to me!... Or can she?
[first lines]
[Mike is speaking on the phone to a potential client with his feet propped on his desk revealing the holes in the soles of his shoes]

You want what? Oh, references. Well, sure, I'd glad to give you some references. You can call Senator Hugh Oglethorpe - no, no, no, you'd better not. I beat Hughie playing golf yesterday. You can call Sid Dreyfuss. Mm-hmm. That's Judge Sidney Dreyfuss, yeah - the State Supreme Court. Oh, that reminds me; I'm supposed to have dinner with him tonight. Pardon me while I make a note of that, will you?
